instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message: This one is dead. I get 12V from 4 pins on power supply to board. Is center pin of the powersupply connector supposed to have any power? No fan spin or chime. I have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and nothing at what I believe is the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> coil. Diode on that coil is .402 and diode check around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> seem to be comparable to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. No signs of liquid and nothing noticeably bad on board. CHecked to see if maybe any caps loose (if it were dropped or something) but best guess is maybe supposed to be voltage from center pin on the power supply and that is issue....

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message:
Unfortunately, no schematics available for Minis.
Do you note any pulse at big coils?
Check at the same time when press the power button.

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message: No pulses at other large coils with power button, just steady 3.3V on the one. So I take it no voltage at middle pin of power supply connector is normal? I did verify that the power button closes the circuit correctly so it works at least. I tried SMC bypass just to see but guessing wont work on a mini...

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message:
Check for short on the 5V USB power rail.
Shorted caps there is classic issue...

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message: No luck on those but was a good thought. Not seeing familiar PP3V42 components but I do have dropping values around the SMC. Any idea if this board should have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>? Some spots I'm getting 3.38V but I think that is actually <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>... If the dropping voltage measurements are supposed to be PP3V42, that would be my issue. Not seeing the familiar coil like whats on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board or 00165. Most of the test points though around the SMC checking with diode are around .712 range... not sure if that could be a tell of any sort. Not shorts though anyway

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message: Not sure how I missed this before. ONe of the coils (looks like L7630 circuit from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board maybe??? P1V05 SO?) It appears I have a dead short on that line zero ohms resistance to ground.

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message:
You can't get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> without <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>; so that's not the issue.

Lift that coil one side and see where the short remains.
What is the exact ohm resistance of the short?

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message: Will do. It is a dead short: 0 ohms

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message:
Just in case, remove RAM and check again.

Could be CPU; can confirm after coil is lifted.

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message: Not good... pulling that coil up, the short is CPU side and I pulled what looks like a <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR> and the leg of that that is shorted is the one that sends power to CPU. Pulled the caps from and resistors near there from that leg just on a hope and a prayer and the short is still there so it appears the short is in the CPU.

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message:
CPU VCORE may have very low value to ground.
But not low value for other CPU voltage, like PCH power.

threads.title: 2014 Mac Mini
threads.message: Yes the resistance here is actually zero ohms
